meta.title: GMAT Quant — Neon Console Guide
meta.description: Offline-first PWA study guide: cheatsheet, patterns, flashcards, quiz mode.

items.title: k-digit / powers
items.body: Rewrite into 2s and 5s, pair to make 10s, then count digits from the 10-power.

items.title: Range (smallest possible overall)
items.body: Make ranges overlap as much as possible: smallest combined range can equal the largest individual range.
items.example: If June range is 20 and July is 25, you can nest June inside July ⇒ overall range = 25.

items.title: Linear word problems
items.body: Use baseline ± (rate × deviation). Words like “over 40” mean (S−40), not S.

items.title: Constant-rate burn/drain
items.body: Remaining fraction = 1 − elapsed/total. If both start equal height, H cancels — it’s pure fractions.

items.title: Cost per unit
items.body: Set simple numbers, compute cost/benefit per unit, then convert to “percent less.” Avoid algebra unless forced.
items.example: If A costs 1.5× but lasts 2.5×, then cost/km scales by 1.5/2.5 = 0.6 ⇒ 40% less.

items.title: Scientific notation + percents
items.example: Total = part / fraction. If 77 is 3×10⁻⁶ of total ⇒ total = 77/(3×10⁻⁶) = (77×10^6)/3.

items.title: Radicals & rationalizing
items.body: Multiply by conjugate to remove radicals in denominators. Expand squares to simplify first.

sections.title: Patterns
sections.subtitle: What these question types are testing

items.title: k-digit via pairing 2s & 5s
items.body: Rewrite 4^n as 2^(2n). Pair 2^k·5^k = 10^k. Try to land on (small number)·10^k, then digits = k+1.

items.title: Smallest combined range = overlap trick
items.body: Nest the smaller interval inside the larger interval. The total range can be as small as the larger range.

items.title: Baseline ± rate×deviation (mpg)
items.body: Start at baseline. Apply each penalty using the correct deviation. “Over 40” forces (S−40).

items.title: Candles: constant-rate burn
items.body: Write remaining height as a fraction of original: A = H(1−m/t), B = H(1−m/2t). Cancel H and solve.

items.title: “Could be > 1” with an upper bound
items.body: Use the maximum allowed x to see if the expression can exceed 1. Watch for cancellations like (1/x)·x.

items.title: Range + total = construction
items.body: Range 2 means only three consecutive values {n, n+1, n+2} are possible. Build one valid distribution that hits the total.

items.q: If you see powers of 4 with powers of 5, what’s the move?
items.a: Rewrite 4^n → 2^(2n). Pair 2^k·5^k = 10^k. Then count digits from the 10-exponent.

items.q: Smallest possible overall range when combining two groups?
items.a: Maximize overlap; the smallest combined range can equal the largest individual range.

items.q: What does “per 10 mph over 40” mean algebraically?
items.a: Use the deviation (S−40). Then apply the rate: 0.5 per 10 → (S−40)/20.

items.q: How do you remove radicals from a denominator like (√a−√b)?
items.a: Multiply by the conjugate (√a+√b). Expand squares first if that simplifies.

items.q: If y increases 10% and you have y² in the denominator, what happens?
items.a: The denominator multiplies by (1.1)² = 1.21, so the whole expression is divided by 1.21.

quiz.p: You see 4^9 · 5^17. What’s the fastest plan?
opts: Rewrite 4^9 as 2^18 and pair 2s with 5s into 10s

quiz.p: Two month ranges are 20 and 25. Smallest possible combined range?
quiz.why: Fully overlap intervals; smallest overall range equals the largest individual range (25).

quiz.p: “Penalty of 0.5 mpg per 10 mph over 40.” Speed is S≥40. Penalty term?
Convert 0.0003% into a decimal (or scientific notation).
If y increases 10% and you have y^2 in the denominator, overall factor is…
quiz.why: Denominator scales by (1.1)^2, so expression divides by 1.21.
